instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SPI_MOSI: What is SPI_MOSI? SPI_MOSI is a signal between the CPU or PCH and the SPI ROM bios chip that is necessary for the machine to POST and boot. If this signal line is corroded or the BIOS chip has failed then you will not get PM_SLP_S4_L and the machine will not boot. Very often this line is corroded by liquid damage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
I have a macbook in that has water damage, when the power cable is plugged in it goes green and then orange, no fan spin is seen.

Damage was sustained on <RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_VFB1_R</SIGNAL>) which had gone high resistance and had corrosion attaching it to the nearby ground plane. This was replaced with another resister and corroded pad re tinned.

There was also corrosion between <CAPACITOR>C1272</CAPACITOR> (PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCACLKPLL) and <CAPACITOR>C1297</CAPACITOR> (PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_VCCUSB3PLL).

There was also a small amount of surface corrosion, but no component damage around <RESISTOR>R5360</RESISTOR>

The following voltage readings were made :
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
8.6v
<RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
8.6v
<RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
3.3v
<RESISTOR>R2094</RESISTOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
8.6v
<CAPACITOR>C7434</CAPACITOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>
18.5v
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>
not - 15.04v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
3.3v
J3501
not ok - 0.340v

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
18.5v
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>
not ok - 15.04v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
3.3v
<RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
3.42v
L7095
ok

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
3.3v
<TRANSISTOR>Q4800</TRANSISTOR>
not ok - 0.063v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
3.3
<CAPACITOR>C5450</CAPACITOR>
not ok - 0.058v

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
3v
<CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>
ok

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
3.3v
<CAPACITOR>C5450</CAPACITOR>
not ok - 0.58v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
5v
<CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR>
ok - 4.97v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
5v
<CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR>
not ok - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
5v
<RESISTOR>R8063</RESISTOR>
not ok - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL>
3.3v
<CAPACITOR>C5460</CAPACITOR>
no ok - 0.038v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
You've posted lot of information, but many confussions.
Also noted wrong assumption; suposing 18.5V means the voltage expected by you from charger.
Charger voltage depends by its type; is marked on it.

Please, stop to post SUPPOSED voltages; we need accurate information.
Seems that you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS but no other voltages; confirm if correct.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Th
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 81659, member: 682"]
You've posted lot of information, but many confussions.
Also noted wrong assumption; suposing 18.5V means the voltage expected by you from charger.
Charger voltage depends by its type; is marked on it.

Please, stop to post SUPPOSED voltages; we need accurate information.
Seems that you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS but no other voltages; confirm if correct.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
[/QUOTE]
 The voltages where I put 'ok' match the voltages listed for that power rail in the schematic. Where I have written 'not ok' I have listed the voltage that was taken as it doesn't match the voltage on the schematic. 

I have shorted <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> with tweezers and saw the voltage temporally drop at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> . I did see fan spin for a moment too, which then stopped. If I repeat this process again I don't appear to be getting fan spin again. The voltage still drops and returns to normal though as before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Check for pulse at both <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

As you get fan spin, means <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> comes on (on that moment).
Check for pulse at all big coils; also at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

BTW, write directly on the Reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
No need to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Ok so both  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>  pulse when triggered.
L7320 - <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> - triggered
 L7310 - <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> - triggered
L7630 - <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_LL</SIGNAL> - triggered
L7430 - <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_LL</SIGNAL> - triggered
L7560 - <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_REG_L</SIGNAL> - has voltage (no change)
L7130 - <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> - has voltage (no change)
L3095 - <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4SW_TBTBST_FET</SIGNAL> - did not trigger
L7701 - <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - did not trigger
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - triggered
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> - did not trigger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Do you mean pulse detected by "triggered"?
If yes, check now for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

Try to start in SMC bypass mode also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Yes I mean pulse detected (triggered)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: pulse detected  at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. If I start in SMC bypass mode, when I press the power button the fan spin for 1 second then stop. Then if I press the power button again they spin and then stop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Do you know how to start in SMC bypass for sure?
Looks like tried incorrect way.
Board should start (or try at least), when release power button, not pressing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Yes hold the power button and plug in the charger. Nothing happens when I do this. If I then let go of the power button after this and start pressing it, the fan then spins for one second each time I press it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Did you maintain power button pressed 5-10s after plug in the charger?

Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Iv just tried a second time, I put my finger on the power button and then plugged in the charger. I kept holding the power button for ten seconds. Nothing at all happened. I then took my finger off the power button and the fan started spinning for a second, stopped for a second, then started for another second and then did nothing else.

I'll check the PLT line in a second.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - pulse detected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Which areas have been affected by liquid?

Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean J6100; you may need to remove it, if corroded.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Ok thanks I’ll check


Damage was sustained on <RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_VFB1_R</SIGNAL>) which had gone high resistance and had corrosion attaching it to the nearby ground plane. This was replaced with another resister and corroded pad re tinned.

There was also corrosion between <CAPACITOR>C1272</CAPACITOR> (PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCACLKPLL) and <CAPACITOR>C1297</CAPACITOR> (PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_VCCUSB3PLL).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Iv had a look and j6100 is clean and has no corrosion at all. Iv had a look on the schemetic and see lots of references to spi, but not sure what you mean by the SPI Bus Series Termination resistors ?.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Ignore that Iv found the page on the schematic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Ok I have tested all resistors and traces and all testing good.

this is a video of what is happening with the board.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://youtube.com/shorts/11JFKIq36qA?feature=share[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
As you've mentioned corrosion under PCH/CPU area, check all voltages from page 11.
Be sure all resistors and small coils are good.
Use the capacitors as test points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR>/21/23 have correct values.
An overvoltage on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> can trigger SMC protection.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR> was the one I replaced as water damaged, it’s within spec.  <RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR> has a very weird reading, so going to change it. <RESISTOR>R7521</RESISTOR> also a bit off so will change that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Ok I took them out of circuit and they test fine, so all three of those are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
Possibly accumulated crap under CPU or/and SMC.
You can try to heat CPU, using quality flux.

Should be good to reball SMC also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Thanks, is the CPU not underfilled on these, or is that just phones and ipads ?. Ill give the SMC a reball. What temp is safe for the CPU ?.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: No sign of corrosion under the SMC, just pulled it and looks fine. Is it possible <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is damaged ?, as <RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR> was damaged. Not sure if the voltages it produces are there?.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Reballed SMC, will has the same problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
No need to melt CPU balls.
No more than 180-200 degress, for 15-20s; sufficient to burn eventually accumulated crap.

You can try known good BIOS first, just in case.
Be sure <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> has good solders and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full"]60262[/ATTACH]
I have just noticed this next to the bios chip, I’m not sure if it is relevant as it doesn’t actually connect to any surface traces. The line is <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> and shows OL at that test point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: In diode mode it shows 0.440 on that test point

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message:
You can't get OL there; in diode mode with red probe at ground.
That means internal trace for <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> is broken.
Check continuity from <RESISTOR>R6112</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R6122</RESISTOR>/27; and the test pad, of course.
Run a wire where is needed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after water damage
threads.message: Ignore that I had it in resistance mode, tests fine in diode mode. Have ordered a bios programmer to see if re flashing it helps,
